patterns: What is the purpose of Rally
What is Rally designed to do
responses: The Rally Analytics Platform is centered around an equity centered approach to continuous learning, through both well-being and academic data, and a set of curated resources for teachers as they work to help each student rebound and thrive.

Rally is designed to help teachers and school leaders reflect on and plan supports for the well-being and academic needs of students, needs that have likely changed or intensified due to the recent disruptions in learning.

patterns: What can I see on Rally
I'm wondering what features are on this website
What does Rally provide to the user
What can I find on Rally
responses: Rally features historical student data, formative and progress monitoring data, an interactive note-taking and goal-setting tool, equity-centered pauses for reflection, and future student performance predictions. The platform also provides links to resources for teachers to help their students catch up and succeed.

patterns: What does Rally intent to do
What can Rally be used to do
responses: It is intended to be used as part of ongoing, collaborative conversations about how best to serve students in and out of school settings, including for planning in-person and remote instruction.

patterns: How are analytics predicted on Rally
responses: The platform analytics predict studentsâ€™ future academic performance based on their historical assessment data and updates those predictions as additional assessments are administered throughout the year. Rally contains guidance for how to interpret the data and connections to supporting resources.

patterns: where does the data come from
how does Rally get all the data
how is Rally able to receive all of this data
responses:
Rally includes student academic performance data that has been authorized for sharing by your district. We are able to provide student data to educators by connecting to existing district systems as part of the on-boarding process. The platform requires a connection to your school district’s identity provider and single-sign-on service to ensure security and privacy of student records.

This includes historical data and updated 20-21 results from your interim and state summative assessments. Education Analytics has partnered with interim assessment vendors to incorporate this data and to receive updated data as frequently as possible during the school year. This ensures that you receive the most current and rigorous academic information about your students in ways that align to reports provided by your assessment vendor.

patterns: How are predictions made for students
I'm curious about how predictions are made for students
responses:
Predictions in Rally represents our best estimate of how your student would have performed had they actually taken the test during a typical school year. Your student’s predicted performance is based on their 2019 state assessment, as well as any interim assessments during the 2019 year for which data are available. 

Predictions will be updated throughout the year when additional assessment data is available.

patterns: how are you reporting Spring 2020 test scores if students did not take tests
how is Spring 2020 data getting reported
my students didn't take tests during Spring 2020, how are you reporting these
responses: The Spring 2020 scores represents our best estimate of how your students would have performed had they actually taken the test during a typical school year. Your student’s predicted performance is based on their 2019 state assessment, as well as any interim assessments taken during the 2019 year. Since the impact of the COVID-19 disruption is not yet known at this time, consider this initial prediction a best guess of the trajectory this student would have been on if 2020 had been a typical school year.

patterns: what do I do if data is missing or wrong for my students
what can I do if there is data gone or not here for my students
what can I do if there is data missing or wrong for my classroom
responses: The data displayed in Rally come from your state summative assessment, district interim assessments, Student Information Systems (SIS), and student well-being survey if your district administered the survey. Your district may not have completed every step in the process to incorporate all of these data elements. You may want to start my contacting your Rally District Administrator to understand where your district is in the process. If there are still identified data issues your District Administrator should contact their Rally representative.

patterns: what do I do if students are missing from my roster
what can I do if there is data gone or not here for my roster
responses: Rally pulls from your district's Student Information System (SIS), so it is possible that your class roster has not been completely scheduled in the SIS. The preferred approach would be to update rosters in the SIS to ensure Rally is pulling in the most up-to-date information. If that is not possible, school leaders can add students to rosters through the Classroom Roster tab of the Administrator Toolbox.

patterns: how might my student's data be protected on Rally
what type of security does my student's data have
what does rally do to protect security and privacy to my students and classrooms
what data security measures are in place for the protection of student and classroom data
Is my student and/or classroom data protected
what privacy acts are in place to defend my student's data
what security compliance is being forced to protect my classroom data
responses:
Rally facilitates efficient access and use of class and student-level data, but these data must also be protected. Rally’s technical system is designed to ensure security and compliance with data security and privacy laws, including the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA). By requiring a connection to your school district’s identity provider and single-sign-on service, Rally ensures that your students’ data is secure and only shown to the appropriate educators. 

Some features of Rally will only be seen by you; for example, any groups of students you create are unique to your Rally account. Notes that you take related to students and choose not to share are only visible to you. However, anything in Rally may be considered part of a student’s academic record and therefore subject to relevant FERPA laws. The platform will remind you of such privacy considerations as you use these features.

patterns: how does Rally work with my other tools
how are my other tools used with Rally
how does all of Rally tools get used together
responses:
Rally can enhance how you use existing tools by offering a more complete set of information about student academics and well-being in one place. Additionally, you can use Rally for direct action by recording notes about each student or creating student groups for instructional planning. 

One of the ways Rally may differ from your other data tools is that predictions of student performance are based on comprehensive information about a student’s past performance, combining interim and state assessment data.

patterns: How can I use Rally to learn about the whole student
How can Rally help me understand my students
I want to learn more about my students
responses:
Rally facilitates a deeper understanding about the “whole student.” By displaying assessment data over the years, information about student well-being, open-ended student quotes, and teacher notes, Rally emphasizes that students are more than their most recent test data. Together, this information can help provide a bigger picture of a student's background and context. 

In addition to reporting on historical well-being and assessment data, Rally incorporates equity pauses. These are brief activities that facilitate reflection about individual students prior to analyzing their data. You can complete equity pauses on your own or bring them to your professional learning community as you consider how to best support your students. There are eight equity pauses embedded throughout the different views of Rally. Each equity pause is also stored in the Information and Resources section.

patterns: how can I use Rally to set goals for my students
where can I set goals for my students
i want to set goals for my class
responses: Rally can help you set goals for your students based on an understanding of their historical academic performance and aligned predictions of their future academic performance based on similar students. Within the individual student view, you can view your student’s past assessment performance in the Assessments Over Time section. You can also see domain-level information for each assessment below. This detailed information can inform goals for each individual student, which can be monitored in each student's notebook.

patterns: how can I use Rally to reflect on equity in my class
how might Rally help me with identify equity in my class
what does Rally do to assist me in spotting equities in my class
what are equity pauses and how might they be used
responses:
Rally incorporates equity pauses and resources to emphasize the need to consider equity in education. Teachers have significant opportunities to take part in the reorganization of systems to create a more equitable future. These resources are meant to make those opportunities more noticeable and actionable. 

Equity pauses are brief activities that facilitate reflection about individual students prior to analyzing their data. You can complete equity pauses on your own or bring them to your professional learning community as you consider how to best support your students. There are eight equity pauses embedded throughout the different views of Rally. Each equity pause is also stored in the Information and Resources section.

patterns: what are the steps for me to access resources
where is the information and resources located
responses: Information and Resources for Rally can be accessed from the teacher and administrator toolboxes within their respective dashboards by clicking "My Dashboard" at the top of the screen. The Information and Resources section provides curated content to support your teaching with tools to see your students through the equity lens, build a culture for student well-being, and strengthen student academic skills in your classes. You can filter the resources by grade and by keyword.  Within each of the sections there are sub-categories. For example Under the equity lens you can find all 8 of the equity pauses, plus other equity resources.

patterns: Why were these resources pick out compared to others
How did Rally recognize these resources
responses: EA worked state and non-profit partners as well as curriculum and assessment experts to curate the resources shared here. In that process, we prioritized high-quality open-source materials from states and other nonprofit organizations to support in teaching and assessing curriculum standards and well-being.

patterns: what information can I see about my entire class
what can I see about my entire class
what does Rally offer for me to see about my entire class
responses:
The class view offers summary information about your class's well-being and academic data. There are three sections in the class view: at-a-glance, performance table, and student roster. 

•  The at-a-glance section summarizes your class data for well-being (once it’s been administered) and academic assessment performance in ELA and math. 
•  The performance table provides a deeper view of well-being or academic data (based on the tab selected) by enabling you to drill into survey and assessment domains. 
•  The student roster allows you to view each students' performance levels and well-being responses for the selected test or survey question. 

\n You can also create student groups on this page, or import saved groups from the Manage Groups tab in the Teacher or Administrator Toolbox.

patterns: what information can I see about my students
what can I see about my students
what does Rally offer for me to see about my students
responses:
The student view offers high-level and detailed information about each of your students and provides you opportunities to reflect and take notes about each student. There are four sections in the student view: a snapshot, at-a-glance, assessments over time, and performance table. 

•  The top snapshot section allows you to select your student, view quotes from this student if they took the well-being survey, and take a quick note.
•  The at-a-glance section shows the most recent survey and assessment data for the selected student.
•  The assessments over time section contains a graph with historical and predicted future student performance in ELA and math. 
•  The performance table shows student responses on survey responses and performance on specific assessment domains.

patterns: How can I use the student notebook
how can I utilize the student notebook
I am confused with how to use the student notebook
what is the purpose for the student notebook
why is the student notebook on Rally
responses: Rally provides notebooks embedded within the teacher toolbox for teachers to take notes related to each individual student. Notes may relate to observations from academic and well-being data, instructional supports provided, or goal identification or completion. There are three ways to access the notebooks: from the teacher dashboard in the teacher toolbox, from a student view page, and from the class roster within the class view.

patterns: Where do class rosters come from and how do I change them
how can I change class rosters
responses: The class rosters in Rally are created with data transferred from your Student Information System (SIS). Rally’s rosters will update whenever we receive new class, teacher, and student information. This could be as frequently as nightly depending on the connection method for your district. If roster data does not look right in Rally, the best approach is to correct the data directly in the SIS. If is not possible to make changes to the SIS, school leaders can manually make edits through the Classroom Roster tab of the Administrator Toolbox make. Note that teachers do not have a Classroom Roster tab.

patterns: how do I add a new class to Rally
want to add a new class to Rally
responses: Rally pulls from your district's Student Information System (SIS), so the preferred approach is to update the classes in the SIS to ensure that Rally is pulling in accurate information. If that is not possible, school leaders can add classes through the Classroom Roster tab of the Administrator Toolbox. These "classes" may correspond to actual classrooms, or may be subsets of students assigned to a particular educator in your building.

patterns: How do I add a new staff member to Rally
What are the steps in adding new staff to Rally
responses: Whenever you create a new class in the Classroom Roster tab of the Administrator Toolbox you will need to assign a teacher to that class. You will be given a list of teachers who are linked to your school in your district's Student Information System (SIS). You can pull from that list of staff when creating new classes. You cannot add a school staff member that is not in the SIS. Please contact your district's HR personnel or SIS administrator to see if a staff member can be added to the SIS.

patterns: I have a question that is not in the FAQ, what do I do
I have a question that is not on the FAQ
I want to ask a question not provided
want to contact the Rally team
reach out to the Rally team
Where is the contact us button
responses: Use the 'Contact Us' button at the bottom of your screen to reach out to the Rally team.

patterns: What does the classroom page offer
What does the classroom view contain
What information does the classroom view include
responses: The class view offers summary information about your classes well being and academic data.
The classroom page offers summary information about your classes well being and academic data.

patterns: What does the student view offer
What does the student view contain
What information does the student view include
responses: The student view offers high level and detailed information about each of your students.

patterns: when might predictions be changed or updated
responses: Predictions will be updated throughout the year when additional data is available.

patterns: where can I find the assessments over time section
where is the location of the assessments over time for a student
responses: Further down, in the student view, you will find the assessments over time section which summarizes historical and predicted future student performance for ELA and Math, a solid line indicates actual scores, while a dash line signals that these are predicted scores

patterns: where can I find the student notebook
where is the location of the student notebook
responses:
You can also open the student notes from the teacher toolbox when you select a student's name from the drop down menu, you'll see the most recent entries for their notebook. There are three sections in the notebook well-being, academic and goals. Within each notebook section, you will see a chronological list of notes for your student. Here you can see all of the notes taken this year in the well-being section of the notebook. You can edit each note by typing directly into it.

When you're done, click save to complete and save your note.

You can also take academic notes for selected student. You can either add a note or edit a note and then assign it to either math or L.A.. Once your note is complete, choose whether or not you'd like this note to be made public. Save your note, then close the notebook tab. The well-being page of the notebook works the same way. The Goals section of the notebook provides a template for setting and monitoring goals for your student. Start by adding a goal. When you're done, choose whether or not you want to make this goal public and hit save. You can open an existing note or goal and update its public or private status. Add notes or mark that a goal has been met. When you're done, don't forget to save your edits.

patterns: where can I find the student groups
where is the location of the student groups
where can I find the manage groups
where is the location of the manage groups
responses: The first location is on the student roster table. Within the class view, this view allows you to make and save student groups according to a particular domain of well-being, English language arts or math. The second location can be found on the dashboard, where the managed groups tab is located in the tool box to create student groups directly from the dashboard.

patterns: how do I make a student groups
how could I use the student groups feature
how do I use the manage groups feature
how do I create a manage groups group
how do I put together a manage groups
responses: Click the manage groups tab, select your class and then click add set of groups and pick a name for the set. A set is a collection of groups around a topic that could be made as random groupings or curated groups of students. Next, select the number of groups you'd like in the set if you'd like for students to randomly populate into groups, select randomly populate. If you want to create your own intentional groupings, simply click generate groups. Once you have created a set of student groups, you can edit the name of each group or add an additional group to the set. You can also add students by clicking and dragging them from the class roster into a group or remove a student from a group. Groups and sets of student groups created in the managed groups to automatically save and can be loaded into the class view. If you no longer need a set of groups, they can be permanently deleted from your view. Note that once you select remove all groups, you will no longer be able to retrieve that set of groups.

patterns: what are student goal used for
what is the goal setting designed for students
responses: Rally will help you set goals for your students based on an understanding of their historical academic performance and aligned predictions of their future academic performance based on similar students.
